title: Cat. 106  Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Aug. 21, 1899
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Aug. 21, 1899  
1899  
Monogram PGO: only state  
Mimeograph in brownish-black ink with touches of pink watercolor, and wood-block print in ocher ink, on cream wove paper; 383 × 497 mm (full sheet); 383 × 250 mm (folded sheet); 32 mm (diameter of printed monogram)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison Collection, 1948.419  
Kornfeld 56 (monogram)  
For the inside and back, see fig. 100.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin produced nine issues of Le sourire (The Smile), his “serious newspaper,” as well as three supplements; this issue is the first and did not contain a supplement. Using the new technology of mimeography that he encountered while clerking as a draftsman in Papeete, he created the satirical newspaper for local monthly distribution. The machine that Gauguin used was likely an Edison Mimeograph Model 0. These devices were manufactured in Chicago by the A. B. Dick Company and had only become available in 1897 (see Technical Overview). So popular was the machine, which greatly improved the efficiency of bureaucratic offices, that by the time Gauguin gained access to one in 1899, he described it as “all the rage.” It is likely that this duplicating technology also appealed to the artist on a conceptual level, considering his history of experimentation with various transfer processes.

The format of Le sourire is not immediately intuitive. The unusual orientation of text relative to the folding of the sheets indicates that the journal was intended to be read by turning the pages from left to right. This issue of Le sourire is the first that Gauguin produced with the hope of using the mimeograph to print multiples of text as well as drawings (see Technical Overview). Unfortunately, the technology had limits that thwarted his aesthetic ambitions; the vignettes sprinkled throughout the text were rendered partially illegible due to broken lines and uneven printing. This issue of the journal was illustrated with mimeographed vignettes (fig. 100.2) and a faint wood-block-printed monogram (fig. 100.3). In later issues of the journal, he turned exclusively to wood-block printing for his illustrations.

The issue was printed by applying brownish-black ink through a mimeograph stencil. The stencil itself was responsible for the grainy appearance of the text and illustrations (see Technical Overview). The vignette on page two is additionally hand colored with touches of pink watercolor (fig. 100.4). It is the only example examined to date for this study in which hand coloring appears. On the last page, the artist’s caricature presides over his writing (fig. 100.5). The wood-block-printed monogram, also on page two, is faintly printed in ocher ink.

The paper that Gauguin selected is only slightly higher quality than newsprint. It is a thin, soft, short-fibered paper with a slight texture that is visible in transmitted light. Because the paper was formatted for use with the mimeograph machine and because Gauguin was notoriously low on money and supplies, it is possible that he procured this paper from the office where he worked and where he returned to do his mimeograph printing. This same paper appears again in Gauguin’s later work, including the transfer drawings Woman with a Cat (cat. 123) and Sister of Charity (cat. 125).

383 × 497 mm (full sheet); 383 × 250 mm (folded sheet); 32 mm (diameter of printed monogram)

The issue is in fair condition. It was mended along the edges and central folds, but it cannot be determined when this was done.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Maurice Gobin (born 1883), Paris, to Carter H. Harrison (1860–1953), June 25, 1948.

Given by Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison, Chicago, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Mimeographed upper left, in brownish-black ink: Gérant / Paul Gauguin / Aôut

Mimeographed upper center, in brownish-black ink: Le Sourire / Journal Serieux / hebdomadaire

Mimeographed upper right, in brownish-black ink: 3 Raira / le numero / – / paraissant le 21

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Gauguin gave his publication the subtitle Journal sérieux for the first four months of its production, but by December 1899, he changed it to Journal méchant (“wicked newspaper”).

Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

For Gauguin’s work in Papeete, see Bengt Danielsson, Gauguin in the South Seas, trans. Reginald Spink (Doubleday, 1964).

“J’ai créé en outre un journal ‘Le Sourire’ autographié Système Edison, qui fait fureur” (I have also created a newspaper, The Smile, using the Edison printing system, which is all the rage). Gauguin to Monfreid, Dec. 1899, in Lettres de Gauguin à Daniel de Monfreid, ed. Annie Joly-Segalen, introduction by Victor Segalen (G. Falaize, 1950), p. 151, no. 59. Translation by the authors.

For more on Gauguin’s experiments with transfer techniques, see Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44. See also Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973).

In later issues of the journal, he turned exclusively to wood-block printing for his illustrations.

Receipt from Maurice Gobin, June 25, 1948, six pages from “Le Sourire,” sold to Mr. Carter H. Harrison, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 106 Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Aug. 21, 1899.

fig. 100.3 Detail of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux (Aug. 21, 1899, top of p. 2) showing the monogram PG printed faintly in ocher ink. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.419.

fig. 100.4 Photomicrograph of a vignette from Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux (Aug. 21, 1899, bottom of p. 3) showing touches of hand-applied pink watercolor. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.419.

fig. 100.5 Detail of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux (Aug. 21, 1899, top of p. 4) showing the mimeographed caricature of the artist. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.419.

fig. 100.1 Inside and back of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Aug. 21, 1899. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.419.

</section>
